Turkish parliament ratifies deal with Russian on building Turkish Stream TASS (2016) December 2, The parliament of Turkey has passed a bill on ratifying an intergovernmental agreement with Russia on constructing the Turkish Stream gas pipeline, the Milliyet daily reported on Dec. 2.
A total of 210 lawmakers out of 223 were in favor of the ratification during the vote, which was held last night. On Nov. 29, the parliament’s foreign relations commission also endorsed the bill.
The Russian authorities announced the Turkish Stream in December 2014 to replace the South Stream gas pipeline project. It was planned that the offshore section of the Turkish Stream gas pipeline would comprise four stretches with a capacity of 15.75 billion cubic meters each.
However, the negotiations on the project were subsequently suspended, including due to the crisis in bilateral relations. After talks held between Turkish President Tayyip Erdogan and Russian leader Vladimir Putin in St. Petersburg in August 2016, a decision was made to resume works under the Turkish Stream gas pipeline project, set up a working group and prepare a roadmap (para 1-4). It’s time to discuss new prospects of cooperation with Russia rather than the recent crisis, Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Çavuşoğlu said in an exclusive interview with TASS ahead of the visit of Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov to Turkey.

"We should not speak about how to return our relations to the pre-crisis level. We should discuss how to develop them further and bring them to new heights," Çavuşoğlu said.

Reasons Turkey might want to cancel it
- if it believed that its relationship with Moscow would preclude close safety and security cooperation with Rosatom. 
-will the Turkish state be ready to share with Rosatom a national security analysis?  
-how sound can security collaboration be between Turkish law enforcement and the Akkuyu plant’s management? 
-How effective could dialogue be if a cyber attack targeted Turkey’s critical electricity infrastructure—including its nuclear power plant—especially given that Russia-based hackers have mounted sustained attacks on Turkish government web sites since the plane incident ?  Reasons Turkey might want to cancel it
-Russia has signed a contract with Egypt and is pursuing opportunities in other countries. 
-the sharp drop in oil prices has dented the amount the Russian state allocates to its nuclear industry,
-doubts about whether Russia can meet its nuclear power plant export commitments to potential new customers. 
-withdrawal from the Akkuyu project would allow Russia to redirect much-needed funds to nuclear export commitments to more friendly countries. ". . . because of its financial exposure, Moscow is under more pressure than Ankara to assess whether the project can actually be completed under these conditions.  " . . . both Ankara and Moscow may have an incentive to end their cooperation, rather than accept risks that could be amplified by worsening political ties. "The main obstacle to denouncing the deal—for either party—is the threat of being liable for sizeable compensation. Interestingly, the Turkey-Russia Intergovernmental Agreement (link in Turkish) that provides the legal framework for the nuclear power project includes no direct compensation provisions. But it does incorporate provisions for the international arbitration of disputes. Turkey and Russia also have a bilateral agreement for the protection of mutual investments that could be used to initiate compensation claims. " . . .  each side will likely refrain from unilateral measures that would trigger compensation claims. As a result, the project is likely to stall, with Turkey raising regulatory obstacles to deter licensing efforts, and Russia less willing to spend significant funds on a project clouded in uncertainty. Akkuyu’s fate will probably remain unclear until either both sides can reach an agreement on compensation, or there is a clear improvement in the political relationship, which at the moment doesn’t look likely.

Despite these decisions on other energy projects, Turkish and Russian authorities have refrained from opining about the future of the Akkuyu nuclear power plant, on which construction was scheduled to begin in 2016. This silence, though, should not be construed as an indication that the future of the project is secure. Rather, it is a reflection of the prevailing uncertainty about the consequences of a unilateral withdrawal. Unlike more traditional nuclear power projects, in which the host state takes on direct or indirect financial liabilities, the build-own-operate model seems to grant Turkey a larger margin in which to maneuver should it want to cancel the project. The main reason Turkey might want to move in this direction would be if it believed that the newly antagonistic relationship with Moscow would preclude close safety and security cooperation with Rosatom. For instance, nuclear-facility builders must plan for the physical protection of a plant based on a threat assessment (known as the design basis threat). To what extent will the Turkish state be ready to share with Rosatom the national security analysis required to come up with the assessment? At the operational phase, how sound can security collaboration be between Turkish law enforcement and the Akkuyu plant’s management? How effective could dialogue be if a cyber attack targeted Turkey’s critical electricity infrastructure—including its nuclear power plant—especially given that Russia-based hackers have mounted sustained attacks on Turkish government web sites since the plane incident ? The unease caused by such questions could lead Turkish authorities to seek to annul the Akkuyu deal. From Russia’s perspective, the Akkuyu project had particular significance as the first time it had facilitated the export of its reactors with the help of a BOO model. Since the Akkuyu deal was agreed in 2010, though, Russia has signed a contract with Egypt on the basis of similar commitments, and is pursuing opportunities in other countries. Meanwhile, the sharp drop in oil prices has soured fiscal balances and dented the amount the Russian state allocates to its nuclear industry, raising doubts about whether Russia can meet its nuclear power plant export commitments to potential new customers. So a withdrawal from the Akkuyu project would allow Russia to redirect much-needed funds to nuclear export commitments to more friendly countries.

It is unlikely that Russia will undertake any further military or other actions to antagonize Turkey that jeopardize the Akkuyu deal or the broader economic relationship with the country.  Initial 2016 predictions for Russia’s economy show that it will shrink in 2016 and Turkey is Russia’s 5th largest trading partner with $25 billion in exports in 2014.   Similarly, Turkey will seek to stabilize the relationship, as Russia is its second most important trading partner and the country needs to expand its energy access, both in terms of total supply and sources. Turkey’s energy needs are predicted to double over the next decade and the country’s traditional sourcing relationship with Iran may now be less certain, as there will be more competition for Iran’s supply. The lifting of economic sanctions on Iran by the U.S. and the EU will free up Iran to trade with both, and the EU in particular is eager to move away from dependence on Russia for natural gas. And, whiie Russia will maintain majority ownership and management of the Akkuyu plant, the plant will also be an important step for Turkey in diversifying into and building its internal capacity to manage nuclear energy.

Rationale : Turkish / Russian proxy conflict in Syria seems likely to continue vs Russia's long-term ally Assad, however any possibility of nuclear capability to an increasingly bitter local enemy seems unlikely -hence closing down of this nuclear plant seems all but inevitable. While one would have thought that after the Turkish strategic blunder (its difficult to characterise purposefully shooting down a Russian plane and killing their pilots as anything else) that Turkey would have taken a deep breath, stepped back and made some suitable nationalistic & diplomatic noises and called it a day... However that assumes a rational state actor (on both sides!) - and while both are bombastic nationalists, Puttin at at least a comprehendible state actor (in purely Russian & domestic terms) while Erdoğan is appearing increasingly irrational, and perhaps isn't listening to advice..
Stiring up a Kurdish civil war (when peace seemed so close), clearly logistically, medically and financially trading/backing backing ISIS; he thought he could scare off the Russian air-strikes against his Turkmen[ISIS?] allies in Syria by shoot-down....Putin however took it very personally and things have escalated from there... So rather than backing down, Erdoğan instead blockaded the Bosphorus to Russian shipping in December.
'Blocking' [aka delaying] of Russian ships in the Bosphorus by Turkey (its good to remember that blockades of critical sea lanes have been seen as acts of war before..) is a significant upping of the ante - and if push comes to shove the space for miscalculation seems increasingly small...especially with two belligerent state actors with their perceived key strategic interests at stake.
http://www.ibtimes.com/russia-turkey-crisis-27-russian-ships-blocked-after-moscow-detains-turkish-vessels-2231946 Similarly the next Russian move in response might even be as provocative as arming the Kurds with heavy weapons, and perhaps (less likely) shielding them from Turkish air-strikes... So in this tightened tension I find Russian continuing of constructing a nuclear reactor for what potentially (at least in Russian military planner's mind's now) must surely be a potential enemy would seem folly. Consequently I think it highly likely that the nuclear power plant project will be mothballed - at the very least until Turkish-Russian relationship soothes over significantly (and with things the way they are in Syria - with Russian plans bombing ISIS aligned Turkmen and oil-tankers in Syria that seems increasingly unlikely). One would hope that diplomats are pointing out to Turkey that NATO exists to protect them, not for a shield in the event of their triggering another Turko-Russian war...? (where its likely there would be much less sympathy in Europe for aiding Turkish backing ISIS in its proxy-war in Syria va Asad, Iran & Russia...) The (hopefully slim) prospect of Turkey agitating the situation with Russia to the point than an inadvertent shooting war is [inadvertently] triggered seems possible.
In the event of Turkey (even accidentally) shooting at Russian Bosphorus shipping, its easy to see how a proxy-war could quickly become something much worse...
(And as we know from past Naval incidents - once combat systems are active the potential for false-positives and defensive/pre-emptive attacks becomes high; as unlike land conflict reaction times are measured in seconds). Shades of Guns of August perhaps..?

I’m new to forecasting. I went through the training videos on the web site and one suggestion was in order to become a better forecaster you need to start forecasting so here I am. I also just read the book superforecasting and am now studying it to gain a greater appreciation for this skill. Below is my outside and inside view of the question. Broadly, projects get canceled more frequently and at a higher rate than I thought. When looking at the Akkuyu nuclear power plant I looked at both Russia and Turkey interests. Russia is facing financial troubles (list below). There are also recent examples (Bulgaria in 2012) and (Ukraine 2015) of canceled projects of Russian nuclear power projects. Taking into consideration that plants close, Russian plants have closed, Russia debt downgraded, Rubble in trouble, military conflict with Turkey, scientist training suspended… it looks like this plant could close. Now when will it close? We have 12 months for this to happen. I also acknowledge I’m having trouble figuring out a timeline. But since we are in a new year we should expect 2-4 plants close up shop Akkuyu could be one. Outside view: There are 440 commercial nuclear power reactors in operation in the world and 65 under construction [1]. There are 180 abandoned, canceled, or unfinished nuclear power plants worldwide [2]. That is roughly 40% of nuclear power plants that don’t ever make it. I can then broadly say if there is 65 plants under construction 40% of those (26) face possible canceling projects if the historical trend continues. I will acknowledge that these numbers are rough. I found another website that said 12% of power plants today are at risk of closing today [10]. I looked at all nuclear power plants in history versus newer projects. I suppose I could split the difference. The point is broadly from an outside view power plants projects stop construction. I looked for the greatest reasons for plants closing and the top three reasons relate to financing, design, and labor markets. I can continue further with “outside view” information but the aforementioned are the biggies. As I think more about the relative positions of the parties, the best strategy for Russia might be to stop work, but not to "officially suspend or cancel."  In either case, the sunk cost is the same.  From the Russian perspective, delay doesn't cost much.  All big projects have delays.  From the Turkish perspective, no electricity gets produced until the plant is built.  Since the plant is Russian BOO (build, own, operate), it's almost a gift to the Turks.  Once the plant begins to operate, the Turks have to pay their utility bills, but until then they hardly pay anything.  If Turkey wants the plant without the Russians, it will need to find someone else to build it.  Good luck with that.  It would probably cost twice as much and the economic proposition would be completely different.  Even setting aside Russian pressure on tourism and Turkish agricultural exports and the not-so-subtle threat to restrict natural gas shipments, Turkey is not in a good negotiating position here.  Once the Russians accept the notion of sunk cost, their BATNA is clearly superior.  Collisions can happen.  Suspension/cancellation stays on the table.  But I'm lowering my forecast.
Economic rational interest trumps conflict hysteria in the long term

Construction has been halted by Rosatom at this point, but this hasn't apparently counted as an official suspension or cancelleation in the terms of this question, since it has not been closed yet. This is a major project with a c.10-15yr time frame and it represents a significant advance for Russia and Rosatom to be invited to build a plant in a NATO country. It would seem to me unlikely that Russia would make a rash decision on this project at this point. This is supported by the measures taken so far by Russia (Agricultural import duties etc.).  I view a cancellation in the relatively short time frame implied by this question as unlikely. It is more likely that Rosatom simply continues its inactivity on construction until further clarity in the relations is established in the coming months.

The project may slow down in 2016 with some temporary suspensions, but Russia's interest in this project is much higher than Turkey's, therefore Russia will not cancel. There is a high probability Turkey may cancel the project if Russia crosses the "red line" and turns to other potential candidate.

The first deputy head of the Duma's United Russia faction also said that on this issue he had a conversation with the leadership of Rosatom. "Currently, the legal entity in Turkey is engaged in obtaining official licenses for energy generation and nuclear power plant construction. The actual construction work has not yet begun," - he said." Four possible explanations, not all of them contradictory:
(a) the Akkuyu subsidy is in the budget, but under a different line, which allows a Rosatom-friendly lawmaker to misdirect his populist comrades;
(b) Russian government has already decided to cut off financing for the project, at least for 2016; if they want to drop the project altogether, they will probably make an announcement;
(c) Rosatom has not given up yet and is looking for outside financing (Russian state banks, foreign investors);
(d) the project has enough funds for 2016 (maybe the 2015 subsidy was supposed to finance the project throughout the next several years), so there's no need for a new federal budget subsidy. (5) Can Turkey deny the project those licenses ("the legal entity in Turkey is engaged in obtaining official licenses for energy generation and nuclear power plant construction")? Maybe, but why give Russia a pretext to pull out (and maybe even avoid penalties) if Russia's bankrolling the project? (6) I'm not even touching the whole viability issue. There is a report (in Russian) that suggest that the whole project is very risky for Rosatom, but I have no idea if the calculations are correct:
http://www.proatom.ru/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=3715
and the author certainly doesn't like the current management of Rosatom:
http://www.proatom.ru/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=3672&mode=flat&order=1&thold=0 (7) Something to keep an eye on:
http://www.akkunpp.com/akkuyu-npp-jsc-ankara
If there's procurement for 2016, then the project has some financing (even if the actual construction is postponed) and, therefore, is not suspended by Russia (although we may be going into the "what is a catch" territory here, again). (8) I have to confess that I feel that "no" should be the status quo here, but I see two reasons to start on the side of "yes":
- it's not clear if the project is financed throughout 2016, so an announcement of suspension/cancellation may come early;
- it's even less clear if the project will be financed for 2017, and if not, an announcement may come at some point in 2016.
